page.title: 06LONDONTHORPE
page.content: Londonthorpe is a small settlement on the edge of the Lincolnshire Limestone Hills, NE of Grantham. An ancient village mentioned in the Domesday Book in 1086 as Lunduntrop. It has a Danish origin, a hilltop encampment for Norse settlers overlooking the wooded Witham Valley. Today it has 30 houses & a pop of 100. St Johns church dates from 1100 AD and is Saxon in style as far as the tower portion which remains can tell us. It was rebuilt and extended at later times especially in 1879 when the bulk of the present building was made. The west wall still has a Norman window and on the south side is a stone crusader. Earlier this century there was a village school, now a bungalow.Newgate Lane used to have a stone wash house belonging to 4 of the dwellings, now a reading room for children. Now a dormitory settlement.
